Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild brings up a general question about navigating a new phase of their life.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The mandatory daily pre-work safety briefing is starting in two minutes.
Story: I was sitting on the edge of my bed, lacing up my steel-toed boots, when my granddaughter poked her head into the room, her eyes wide and uncertain. “Grandma, how did you know what to do when you started something new?” she asked, her voice barely above a whisper. My heart ached to gather her close, to share the stories and lessons I’d learned over decades, to be the steady hand she needed. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: the safety briefing at the site would start in two minutes, and missing it meant risking a reprimand or worse, a suspension. The expectation was clear—be present, be alert, be part of the team. Yet here was my granddaughter, looking to me for guidance, expecting the wisdom only a grandmother could give. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, the hard hat and the gentle hand, the urgency of the job and the timelessness of family. My mind raced, torn between the demands of the site and the needs of my family, knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
